definitions.definition: the hot gas that water changes into when it boils

examples.text: Steam rose from the boiling kettle.
a Turkish steam bath
Steam rose from her mug of cocoa.
The hotel has a steam room.
The saucepan puffed little jets of steam.

definitions.definition: the power that is produced from steam under pressure, used to operate engines, machines, etc.

examples.text: the introduction of steam in the 18th century
steam power
the steam age
a **steam train/engine**
The engine is driven by steam.

definitions.definition: very small drops of water that form in the air or on cold surfaces when warm air suddenly cools

examples.text: She wiped the steam from her glasses.

definitions.definition: to get rid of your energy, anger or strong emotions by doing something active or noisy

examples.text: I went for a long walk to let off steam.
I like blowing off steam and I like saying things that shock people.

definitions.definition: with as much speed or energy as possible

examples.text: Business picked up at the beginning of the year and now it is full steam ahead.
The team is working full steam on the next release.
All of the major players are operating at full steam.

definitions.definition: to go somewhere without help from other people

examples.text: I’ll get to the party under my own steam.

definitions.definition: to become gradually more powerful, active, etc.

examples.text: His election campaign is beginning to get up steam.

definitions.definition: the pressure produced by steam in a small space

examples.text: The old engine still manages to build up a good head of steam.

definitions.definition: a situation in which somebody/something becomes gradually more active or successful

examples.text: This campaign has been steadily **building up a head of steam**.
United have recently gathered a head of steam in the title race.

definitions.definition: to lose energy and enthusiasm and stop doing something, or do it less well

wordOrigin: Old English stēam ‘vapour’, stēman ‘emit a scent, be exhaled’, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch stoom ‘steam’.
